column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat|salience|identity
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Proof
#Text=The proof proceeds by the Principle of Mathematical Induction on the number of vertices .
#Text=For all n ∈ N>0 , let P ( n ) be the proposition : Gn can be assigned a proper vertex k - coloring such that k ≤ 5 .
#Text=Basis for the Induction
#Text=P ( r ) is trivially true for 1 ≤ r ≤ 5 , as there are no more than 5 vertices to be colored .
#Text=This is our basis for the induction .
#Text=Induction Hypothesis
#Text=Now we need to show that , if P ( r ) is true , where r ≥ 5 , then it logically follows that P ( r + 1 ) is true .
#Text=So this is our induction hypothesis : Gr can be assigned a proper vertex k - coloring such that k ≤ 5 .
#Text=Then we need to show : Gr+1 can be assigned a proper vertex k - coloring such that k ≤ 5 .
#Text=Induction Step
#Text=This is our induction step :
#Text=According to the Minimum Degree Bound for Simple Planar Graph , Gr+1 has at least one vertex with at most 5 edges .
#Text=Let this vertex be labeled x .
#Text=Remove vertex x from Gr+1 to create another graph , G′r.
#Text=By the induction hypothesis , G′r is five - colorable .
#Text=Suppose all five colors were not connected to x .
#Text=Then we can give x the missing color and thus five - color Gr+1 .
#Text=Suppose all five colors are connected to x .
#Text=Then examine the five vertices x was adjacent to .
#Text=Call them y1 , y2 , y3 , y4 and y5 in clockwise order around x .
#Text=Let y1 , y2 , y3 , y4 and y5 be colored respectively by colors c1 , c2 , c3 , c4 and c5 .
#Text=Let us denote Hi,j a subgraph of G′r induced by the vertices colored with ci and cj .
#Text=Consider H1,3 .
#Text=Suppose there exists no path between y1 and y3 in H1,3 .
#Text=Thus , H1,3 is disconnected into two components .
#Text=We can , then , interchange the colors c1 and c3 in the component that is connected to y1 .
#Text=Thus x is no longer adjacent to a vertex of color c1 , so x can be colored c1 .
#Text=Suppose there exists a path between y1 and y3 in H1,3 .
#Text=Including the vertex x in this path we get a circuit C .
#Text=Since we indexed the vertices y1 , y2 , y3 , y4 and y5 clockwise , exactly one of the vertices y2 and y4 is inside C .
#Text=Hence , y2 and y4 are in different connected components of H2,4
#Text=Then we can switch colors c2 and c4 in the component of H2,4 that is connected to y2 .
#Text=Now x is no longer adjacent to a vertex of color c2 , so we can color it c2 .
#Text=This graph illustrates the case in which the path from y1 to y3 can be completed .
#Text=Blue = c1 , Yellow = c2 , Red = c3 , Green = c4 , Turquoise = c5 .
#Text=The dotted lines represent edges and vertices that might exist , as this is simply a fairly minimal example graph that matches the conditions .
#Text=So P ( r ) ⟹ P ( r + 1 ) and the result follows by the Principle of Mathematical Induction .
#Text=Therefore :
#Text=For all n ∈ N>0 , Gn can be assigned a proper vertex k - coloring such that k ≤ 5 .
